</ul>
</nav>
<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">EAE3562</span> - Ore deposit geology<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-EAE3562">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-earth-atmosphere-and-environment.html">School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Andrew Tomkins">Dr Andrew Tomkins</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Andrew Tomkins">Dr Andrew Tomkins</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=EAE3562&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-EAE3562">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Two of <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/EAE2511.html">EAE2511</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/EAE2522.html">EAE2522</a></span>, ESC2111 or ESC2122</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ESC3162</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This subject is an introduction to classification, distribution and characteristics of metalliferous ore deposits. An understanding of ore deposit genesis is developed via an Earth Systems approach. The tectonic settings of ore deposits are considered within the context of the plate tectonic paradigm, and global metallogenic events throughout Earth's history. This includes a brief introduction to the minerals industry, including mining and exploration practices. Practical classes will examine sample sets from around the world and focus on developing and understanding of ore deposit genesis, and on developing skills suitable for the minerals industry. Fieldwork consists of an excursion to examine the ore deposits of Victoria.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Recognise and describe different styles of mineralisation and associated alteration in rock specimens and thin sections.</li>
<li>Describe the characteristic mineralogical, structural and host-rock features of a range of important mineral deposit types.</li>
<li>Explain the current hypotheses for genesis of a range of mineral deposit types.</li>
<li>Combine scientific data to form a hypothesis that can be used in mineral exploration for a range of ore deposit types.</li>
<li>Combine scientific data to design and evaluate strategies to efficiently and economically extract ores from known mineral deposits.</li>
<li>Work as a geologist in the minerals industry.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50% (Hurdle)</p>
<p>Practical Examination: 10%</p>
<p>Laboratory work/assignments/field excursions: 40%</p>
<p>Hurdle requirement: Students must pass the theory examination to achieve an overall pass grade. Students who do not pass the theory examination will receive a mark of  48%, unless their aggregate mark is lower in which case that mark will be recorded</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>One 2-hour workshop and</li>
<li>One 3-hour workshop per week and</li>
<li>One 1-day field excursion</li>
</ul><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/earth-science">Earth science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3852</span> - Contemporary issues in social science research<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3852">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-sociology.html">Sociology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Narelle Warren">Dr Narelle Warren</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Narelle Warren">Dr Narelle Warren</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS3852&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3852">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of second-year Arts units.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>BHS3130, ATS3749, SCY2150, AZA3852</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>In this unit, students will identify an issue of interest to them drawn from their undergraduate studies in Behavioural studies, Sociology and/or Gender Studies. Using this topic, students will undertake an extensive review of the relevant academic literature and complete an independent research exercise exploring this topic. This research will be supervised by the Unit Coordinator with input from other staff as appropriate.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon completion of this unit, students will have:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Developed extensive knowledge of a significant issue in contemporary social sciences;</li>
<li>Engaged with a variety of critical and theoretical debates about this issue;</li>
<li>Developed the ability to critically evaluate the extant literature about this issue;</li>
<li>Knowledge of a range of methodological approaches that have been used to examine this issue;</li>
<li>Developed the ability to communicate in both oral and written formats about this issue;</li>
<li>Independently developed and completed a significant piece of research.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/criminology">Criminology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/human-geography">Human geography</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/indigenous-cultures-and-histories">Indigenous cultures and histories</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/sociology">Sociology</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2251</span> - Cuba study tour<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2251">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-spanish-and-latin-american-studies.html">Spanish and Latin American Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Carlos Uxo">Dr Carlos Uxo</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Carlos Uxo">Dr Carlos Uxo</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2251&amp;tpCode=T1-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 1</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2251">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-overseas.html">Overseas</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Term 1 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of first-year Arts units.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS3251.html">ATS3251</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><ul>
<li>This unit is an <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad">international study program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">international study program (<a href="http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad">http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad</a>)</span> that requires an application to be enrolled and may incur additional cost.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered in <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">non-standard teaching periods</a><span class="hbk-print-url">non-standard teaching periods (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This study tour offers a unique environment for students to engage with the history politics and culture of Cuba. Students will undertake a two-week intensive stay in Cuba where they will have the opportunity to engage with academics, activists and leading cultural figures. Students will be asked to engage with some of key challenges facing Cuba today and to consider these in a broader global context. A key component of this study tour will be directed at developing students' cultural literacy.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>develop awareness of the contemporary Cuban context;</li>
<li>understand the global position of Cuba and the historical forces that shaped the revolution and continue to impact the nation today;</li>
<li>communicate an academic understanding of key issues/challenges in the region;</li>
<li>demonstrate intercultural competence in practice and a capacity for teamwork.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Off-campus attendance requirements</h2>
<div>
<p></p><p>Two week intensive study tour of Cuba (Havana, Santa Clara, Trinidad)</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/cultural-competence">Cultural competence</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/international-studies">International studies</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/spanish-and-latin-american-studies">Spanish and Latin American studies</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MBA5225</span> - Global executive MBA innovation I<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 3, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MBA5225">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Patrick Butler">Professor Patrick Butler</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Patrick Butler">Professor Patrick Butler</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MBA5225&amp;tpCode=MBA-TP3-01&amp;tpYear=2019">MBA Teaching Period 3</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MBA5225">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>MBA Teaching Period 3 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MBA5221.html">MBA5221</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MBA5222.html">MBA5222</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MBA5223.html">MBA5223</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MBA5224.html">MBA5224</a></span>.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MBA5226.html">MBA5226</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Global Executive MBA Innovation I unit comprises two component topics: China Business Strategy and Global Executive MBA Business Project II.</p>
<p>China Business Strategy is co-created with faculty at a leading Chinese business school and taught at their campus. The topics covered include China's transformation and its global implications, comparative analysis of Chinese and other business models, and strategies for entering the China market. Expert guest speakers and local company visits provide opportunities for engagement with industry.</p>
<p>Global Executive Business Project II is the second in the series of applied consulting projects, in which teams of students undertake an international business project for an Australia-based business in the international market. Assignments in this module emphasise innovation and technology, and can involve market feasibility assessment, resourcing projects, evaluation of global best practice or business relationship development. The international market research and related business consulting skills developed earlier will be applied.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals of this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>explore and evaluate the political, economic and commercial issues relating to the role and influence of China and the implications for Australia-based business</li>
<li>demonstrate the ability to analyse and synthesise a complex, international business situation and develop appropriate recommendations</li>
<li>demonstrate the ability to manage a consulting client relationship and provide a professional presentation and report that integrate academic learning and business outcomes.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average six/eight hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

</ul>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2305</span> - Digital humanities: Expanding research paradigms<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2305">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-languages-literatures-cultures-and-linguistics.html">School of Languages, Literatures, Cultures and Linguistics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Simon Musgrave">Dr Simon Musgrave</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Simon Musgrave">Dr Simon Musgrave</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2305&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2305">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of first-year Arts units.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS3305</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit examines the application of digital technologies (beyond textual analysis) in humanities research, covering the methods used to make data accessible, the analytic techniques which are thereby enabled, and the dissemination of research results through new modes of publication. The unit will be based on active learning and will enhance and consolidate students' academic and research abilities. It will also guide students to an understanding of the potential of applying new analytic tools to problems in various humanities disciplines and will stimulate team-work and collaboration, creating a pool of transferable skills that students can acquire and practice, and encouraging students to make productive links between theoretical ideas and practical applications.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>address research questions in the digital humanities which require non-textual data;</li>
<li>understand how non-textual data can be made accessible to analysis;</li>
<li>understand which analytic techniques are appropriate to particular kinds of data;</li>
<li>analyse project requirements and cooperate to complete a project;</li>
<li>use innovative means to communicate their subject knowledge and disciplinary approach to a wider public.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/digital-humanities">Digital humanities</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">
<!-- breadcrumbs -->
<nav class="breadcrumbs mobile-hidden" id="breadcrumbs">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3612</span> - The Renaissance in Florence<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3612">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-history.html">History</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Peter Howard">Associate Professor Peter Howard</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Peter Howard">Associate Professor Peter Howard</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3612">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of second-year Arts units.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS2612.html">ATS2612</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><ul>
<li>This unit is an <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad">international study program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">international study program (<a href="http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad">http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad</a>)</span> that requires an application to be enrolled and may incur additional cost.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered as part of the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html">Summer Arts Program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Summer Arts Program (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html">http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html</a>)</span>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This intensive course of 4-week's duration departs from Melbourne in mid-November. It involves interdisciplinary study, conducted in the city itself, of the political, social and cultural history of Florence, from the late thirteenth to the early sixteenth centuries, with particular reference to the Renaissance period. Students who have not passed <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS1316.html">ATS1316</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS1317.html">ATS1317</a></span> should do the preliminary reading with great care.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Students successfully completing this unit will be expected to demonstrate:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>A knowledge of the city of Florence itself - including its churches, palaces, museums, piazzas, monuments and streets - as an artefact of its complex history</li>
<li>The development of the requisite skills to interpret the Renaissance aspects of that artefact within an historical framework</li>
<li>Enhanced skills in the critical and analytical reading of a variety of texts, including contemporary documents, religious and polemical literature, historical scholarship, physical monuments and visual representations</li>
<li>An acquaintance with the considerable body of knowledge that has been built up about late medieval and Renaissance Florence (in the context of Italian history in general)</li>
<li>A critical understanding of this fascinating society and its historiography</li>
<li>The ability to use this knowledge (1, 3, 4, 5) and these skills (2) as a capital source for contributing to an understanding of the Renaissance city, its society and culture.

<p>Students successfully completing ATS3612 will, in addition:</p></li>
<li>Be capable of independently devising and executing an advanced research project in the above areas of study, based predominantly on primary sources.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement. + Additional requirements + This unit is taught intensively at Prato</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2001.html">Bachelor of Global Studies</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Bachelor of Global Studies (<a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2001.html">http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2001.html</a>)</span></p>
<p><a href="../aos/cultural-competence">Cultural competence</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/history">History</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MKF5630</span> - Services marketing<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MKF5630">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-marketing.html">Department of Marketing</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Samir Gupta">Dr Samir Gupta</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Samir Gupta">Dr Samir Gupta</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MKF5630&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MKF5630">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus</a>)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Students must have passed <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKF5955.html">MKF5955</a></span> or equivalent, or be enrolled in course B6010, or be granted permission by the Chief Examiner to undertake this unit.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>An in-depth analysis of the marketing techniques that apply to service organisations and industries including service design and delivery, customer service, service quality measurement and internal marketing.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>gain an appreciation of the unique challenges inherent in marketing and managing services and developing and delivering quality services</li>
<li>integrate the strategies, tools and approaches for addressing the unique challenges  associated with the marketing of services</li>
<li>apply a knowledge of service quality to an actual  business context</li>
<li>become a more successful and effective manager and consumer through the understanding of the design, delivery and communication  of the service offer</li>
<li>explain  the inter-functional coordination necessary to deliver a quality service.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">IDE2303</span> - Ergonomics<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-IDE2303">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mark Richardson">Mr Mark Richardson</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Tahl Swieca">Mr Tahl Swieca</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-IDE2303">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/IDE2701.html">IDE2701</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OHS1000.html">OHS1000</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit concerns the matching of products to the capabilities of the human body (Anthropometrics) and to the surroundings in which human beings live and work. There is particular reference to safety, usability specification and testing, and the commercial and legal aspects of product ergonomics.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Understand the principles and application of ergonomics;</li>
<li>Be capable of optimising ergonomics in design;</li>
<li>Be able to develop ergonomic check lists for products;</li>
<li>Understand and practice the rules of occupational health and safety in force in the industrial design studio.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Practical exercises (80%)</p>
<p>Class tests (20%)</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including a 1-hour lecture, 2 hours of tutorials and 9 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_pha"><span class="unitcode">BPS2042</span> - Drug development<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BPS2042">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_pha">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-pha.html">Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ben Boyd">Dr Ben Boyd</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ben Boyd">Dr Ben Boyd</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BPS2042&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BPS2042">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-parkville.html">Parkville</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BPS1032.html">BPS1032</a></span> Physical chemistry II: Solutions, surfaces and solids</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BPS1042.html">BPS1042</a></span> Pharmaceutical Science in context</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will take students through the process of developing a drug candidate into a registered pharmaceutical product. This encompasses: pre-clinical development, including drug formulation based on the pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic and toxicological profile of a drug candidate; clinical trial regulation and design; intellectual property and marketing considerations. Students will be introduced to the regulatory and commercial requirements as well as the scientific concepts underpinning the drug development processes.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>After completing this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Explain the scientific and regulatory stages involved in taking a drug candidate to a registered pharmaceutical product.</li>
<li>Design and conduct pre-formulation tests to inform formulation decisions.</li>
<li>Evaluate formulation options for a drug candidate with regard to medical, technical and commercialisation considerations.</li>
<li>Propose pre-clinical tests for a drug candidate to provide evidence for its safety.5. Differentiate between the phases of a clinical trial.</li>
<li>Discuss the commercial lifecycle of a pharmaceutical product, the importance of intellectual property and marketing considerations.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>End-of-semester examination (50%) and in-semester assessment (50%)</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Twenty-four 1-hour practicals</li>
<li>Six 4-hour practicals</li>
<li>Six 2-hour workshops</li>
</ul><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Additional information on this unit is available from the faculty at:</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="https://www.monash.edu/pharm/students/undergrad/course-information/bpharmsci">https://www.monash.edu/pharm/students/undergrad/course-information/bpharmsci</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MGS5000</span> - Introductory management research methods<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MGS5000">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-management.html">Department of Management</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ilse Niemann-Struweg">Associate Professor Ilse Niemann-Struweg</a>
        
        (Term 1)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=HB Klopper">Professor HB Klopper</a>
        
        (Term 3)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ilse Niemann-Struweg">Associate Professor Ilse Niemann-Struweg</a>
        
        (Term 1)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=HB Klopper">Professor HB Klopper</a>
        
        (Term 3)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGS5000&amp;tpCode=T1-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 1</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGS5000&amp;tpCode=T3-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 3</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MGS5000">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-south-africa.html">South Africa</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Term 1 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li><li>Term 3 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BEW4000.html">BEW4000</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGX5000.html">MGX5000</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Basic introduction to research design in management; types of research designs; qualitative and quantitative data collection and measurement techniques; coding data; reliability and validity; qualitative and quantitative methods of analysis; interpreting and discussing results; structuring and writing the research report; integrating individual research into overall management literature.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>critically analyse and interpret basic research designs in the management discipline</li>
<li>construct research questions grounded in a theoretical and conceptual framework</li>
<li>assess the appropriateness, types, and use of qualitative and quantitative data collection and analysis techniques as a means of investigating and answering research questions in the management discipline</li>
<li>identify, search for, and locate secondary data and knowledge relevant to management research, as well as understanding the process of generating or collecting primary data</li>
<li>develop academic writing skills appropriate to the discipline for reporting on business management research projects.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">MEC4425</span> - Micro/nano solid and fluid mechanics<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MEC4425">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-mechanical-and-aerospace-engineering.html">Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Davies">Professor Chris Davies</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mainak Majumder">Dr Mainak Majumder</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MEC4425&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MEC4425">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>(<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MEC3451.html">MEC3451</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MEC3453.html">MEC3453</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MEC3455.html">MEC3455</a></span>) or (120 points and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/TRC2200.html">TRC2200</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/TRC3200.html">TRC3200</a></span>)</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Introducing micro and nano-technology in the design of next-generation microelectromechanical systems, microfluidic devices and biomedical applications. Basic concepts and physics of small-scale systems are covered. Topics include: scaling effects, nanofabrication techniques, continuum mechanical theories, low Reynolds number flows, capillary effects and interfacial flows, flows in channels of arbitrary dimensions, convective-diffusive mass transport, electro hydrodynamics including classical double layer theory, electrophoresis, electro-osmosis, dielectric polarisation and dielectrophoresis. The course also focuses on device applications, specifically MEMS sensors and actuators and lab-on-chip devices, through hands-on laboratory sessions (held at Melbourne Centre for Nanofabrication).</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>To instill:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Exposure to the emerging fields of micro and nano technology, particularly for biomedical engineering</li>
<li>Thorough understanding of the physical behaviour of solids and fluids at the micron and nanometer length scales through continuum and molecular theories</li>
<li>An understanding of the difficulties in fabrication, manipulation, and imaging of components at the micro scale and beyond</li>
<li>An appreciation of the various fluid transport mechanisms in micro/nano channels or devices and physical interaction mechanisms in solids at the micro/nano scale</li>
<li>Knowledge in the design of micro/nano-electro-mechanical-systems and micro/nano-fluidic devices for various bio-applications

<p>To develop the ability to:</p></li>
<li>Construct models of micro/nano components and systems</li>
<li>Solve the fundamental equations of motion governing the dynamics of such systems analytically, semi-analytically or using numerical techniques to understand their behaviour for prediction and design</li>
<li>Apply the knowledge provided in the course for the design of practical micro/nano devices</li>
<li>Know where and how to continue learning on advanced and/or new topics in micro/nano solid and fluid mechanics.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 40%</p>
<p>Final Examination (2 hours): 60%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit. Students failing to achieve this requirement will be given a maximum of 45% in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>3 hours lectures, 3 hours practical classes and 6 hours of private study per week</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/mechanical-engineering">Mechanical Engineering</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT3048</span> - Industry experience studio project 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT3048">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_it">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-it.html">Information Technology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Peter Serwylo">Dr Peter Serwylo</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT3048&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT3048&amp;tpCode=SSA-02&amp;tpYear=2019">Summer semester A</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT3048">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Summer semester A 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-south-africa.html">South Africa</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT3047.html">FIT3047</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>CPE3200, CPE3300, CSE3200, CSE3301, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT2032.html">FIT2032</a></span>, FIT3015, FIT3016, FIT3017, FIT3025, FIT3026, FIT3038, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT3039.html">FIT3039</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT3040.html">FIT3040</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT3045.html">FIT3045</a></span>, GCO3819, GCO3700, GCO3800, GCO3900, GCO3800A, IMS3000, IMS3501, IMS3502</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>In their final year of study, students are given the opportunity to develop new skills and apply the knowledge and skills they have gained, in the development of an IT application for a real world client. In teams, students design, develop and deliver an IT applications for a client, manage the project through all its development stages, communicate effectively with all project stakeholders and develop project documentation to a professional standard. Students also present their project work to academics and other groups, attend unit seminars, and contribute in a professional and committed manner to the work of their team.</p>
<p>FIT3048 is the second of two industry experience units for most majors in the Bachelor of Information Technology and Systems, Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences, Bachelor of Business Information Systems and Bachelor of Information Technology. Students must enrol in and pass FIT3048 after successful completion of <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT3047.html">FIT3047</a></span> to complete their industry experience project requirements.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>apply, in a practical setting, aspects of the theoretical work covered in their course;</li>
<li>develop an IT application using a prescribed methodology, conducting all activities associated with the development methodology;</li>
<li>work with clients or client representatives, communicating effectively with them to meet their requirements;</li>
<li>operate effectively as a member of a development team;</li>
<li>evaluate, assess and communicate both personal and team progress and learning, thus engaging in meaningful reflective practice;</li>
<li>explain the roles and responsibilities of clients, system users, service providers, management and developers in the implementation phase of an IT project;</li>
<li>develop documentation and processes that can be used to implement and maintain an IT system.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>In-semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload equals 12 hours per week comprising:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="a">
<li>Contact hours for on-campus students:

<ul>
<li>4-5 hours of seminars, studios, laboratories or supervisor meetings (depending on campus location)</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Study schedule for off-campus students:

<ul>
<li>Off-campus students generally do not attend seminar and lab sessions, however should plan to spend equivalent time working through the relevant resources and participating in discussion groups each week.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Additional requirements (all students):

<ul>
<li>A minimum of 8 hours independent study and team work per week for completing a range of systems development activities.</li>
</ul></li>
</ol><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MGX3100</span> - Corporate social responsibility and business ethics<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MGX3100">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-management.html">Department of Management</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Elizabeth Prior Jonson">Dr Elizabeth Prior Jonson</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Elizabeth Prior Jonson">Dr Elizabeth Prior Jonson</a>
        
        (Caulfield and Prato)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Priya Sharma">Ms Priya Sharma</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGX3100&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGX3100&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGX3100&amp;tpCode=WS-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Winter semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MGX3100">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-prato.html">Prato</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Winter semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Completion of 12 units (72 points) of study</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Do corporations have any responsibilities beyond profit maximisation? To what extent should business activities be left to the operation of the free market and to what extent should they be regulated through internal and external mechanisms? This unit examines the theoretical foundations of the different answers that have been given to these two fundamental questions. More specifically it examines the topics of ethical issues in marketing and advertising, climate change and environmental protection regulation and corporate governance, human resource management and social accounting.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>identify important ethical issues that arise in various business contexts</li>
<li>explain the implications of adopting different approaches to Corporate Social Responsibility</li>
<li>critically assess the strengths and weaknesses of the different approaches to Corporate Social Responsibility</li>
<li>critically assess the strengths and weaknesses of different mechanisms for regulating business behaviour</li>
<li>apply different approaches to Corporate Social Responsibility and different approaches to regulation to issues specific to marketing, HRM, environment and social accounting.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 60% + Examination: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3825</span> - Western art music in the 20th and 21st century<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3825">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-sir-zelman-cowen-school-of-music.html">Sir Zelman Cowen School of Music</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Adrian McNeil">Dr Adrian McNeil</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Adrian McNeil">Dr Adrian McNeil</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3825">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of second-year Arts units.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit investigates the primary musical styles and compositional trends of the twentieth and twenty-first century. The unit analyses representative source works and discusses major musical figures of the period. Topics may include the transition from nineteenth century Romanticism, impressionism, expressionism, the atonal revolution, neo-classicism, the twelve-tone system, serialism (including integral serialism), constructivism (electronic music and extended techniques), indeterminacy, neo-Romanticism and minimalism. The unit also considers Contemporary Australian within this broad context.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon completion of the unit, students are able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Demonstrate in-depth knowledge of the major trends of twentieth-century composition, in particular, and the ways in which these trends relate to one another;</li>
<li>Analyse specific areas of twentieth-century music in some depth, providing further insight into the styles, composers and works important to the specific area in question;</li>
<li>Understand the principles of modern musical notation (i.e., graphic notation).</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/composition-and-music-technology">Composition and music technology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/ethnomusicology-and-musicology">Ethnomusicology and musicology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/music">Music</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/music-performance">Music performance</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">EAE3022</span> - Hydrogeology<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-EAE3022">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-earth-atmosphere-and-environment.html">School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ian Cartwright">Professor Ian Cartwright</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ian Cartwright">Professor Ian Cartwright</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=EAE3022&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-EAE3022">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>6 points of second year  EAE,  ESC, or ATS units managed by the School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ESC3190 and;</p>
<p>Permission by the unit coordinator is required for students in S6002 who are undertaking the Environmental Security (Science) specialisation.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Groundwater is a critical resource and an essential component of the natural environment. This unit addresses groundwater flow and the hydrological cycle, groundwater chemistry and the origins of solutes in water, use of isotopic tracers to understand hydrological processes, the interaction between groundwater and surface water, groundwater as a resource, and contamination of groundwater. These topics are essential for understanding and managing groundwater and surface water resources and for environmental management.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe the physical movement of water within the hydrological cycle;</li>
<li>Determine the origins of solutes in water and how solute chemistry informs our understanding of hydrological processes;</li>
<li>Discuss concepts of groundwater residence times and how these impact on the sustainable management of water resources;</li>
<li>Explain the role of groundwater in maintaining river flows and sustaining ecosystems;</li>
<li>Indicate the main threats to groundwater, including pollution, pumping, and climate or land use change and also be able to identify management and mitigation strategies.</li>
<li>Interpret and integrate hydrological data.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 40%</p>
<p>Assessed practical work: 35%</p>
<p>Individual or group presentations/group work: 15%</p>
<p>Field trip assessment: 10%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>One 2-hour workshop and</li>
<li>One 3-hour workshop per week</li>
<li>One 1-day field trip on a weekend during the semester</li>
</ul><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/earth-science">Earth science</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/environmental-science">Environmental science</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/geographical-science">Geographical science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">CIV6314</span> - Transport planning and policy<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">0 points, SCA Band 2, 0.000 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-CIV6314">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-civil-engineering.html">Department of Civil Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jeff Walker">Professor Jeff Walker</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Geoff Rose">Professor Geoff Rose</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=CIV6314&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-CIV6314">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>This unit is available only to Engineering PhD students.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit introduces students to contemporary issues in transport planning. The concept of sustainable transport is introduced along with the steps in the transport planning process. Supply and demand oriented approaches to addressing transport challenges are reviewed and travel demand management is placed into context. The characteristics of transport modes and travel demand patterns are used to provide a framework for considering the suitability of a particular transport mode for a particular context. Travel survey methods are considered with an emphasis on the role of survey design and administration in the collection of useful travel survey data.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>explain the framework within which transport planning is conducted and the foundations for the formulation of transport policy</li>
<li>identify the range, potential impact, supply and demand oriented solutions to address transport and associated environmental problems within a sustainability context</li>
<li>evaluate the performance, impacts and costs of various transport mode (passenger and freight) and the factors influencing the level, pattern and trends in travel demand</li>
<li>explain the issues relevant to selecting a mode for a particular transport task</li>
<li>evaluate the factors underpinning transport surveys including sample design, questionnaire design, data editing and expansion.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 50%</p>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>On-campus - 2 hours lectures, 2 hours practice class and 8 hours of private study per week.</p>
<p>Off-campus - 150 hours study</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Civil Engineering</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">BFW3841</span> - Credit analysis and lending management<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BFW3841">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-banking-and-finance.html">Department of Banking and Finance</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Sockalingam Ramasamy">Dr Sockalingam Ramasamy</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BFW3841&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BFW3841&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BFW3841">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BFW2401.html">BFW2401</a></span> and BFW2631 or equivalent.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BFF3841.html">BFF3841</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Lending environment; decision making and organisation of lending, lending policies and controls; behavioural aspects of decision making and decision-makers; retail, commercial and corporate lending; business expansions; off balance sheet lending; loan management and problem loans.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>apply appropriate analysis techniques to particular loan facilities</li>
<li>analyse the risk return characteristics (and pricing) of a loan application</li>
<li>examine the major types of lending products and gain the ability to match these products to customer needs</li>
<li>investigate  the behavioural aspects of decision making and decision makers</li>
<li>describe statistical techniques used in decision making at the approval, monitoring and termination stages of lending</li>
<li>apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills to individual and/or group activities dealing with lending decisions and demonstrate in an individual summative assessment task the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by BFW3841.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 40% + Examination: 60%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>
